>   >   I have followed this discussion with great interest an=
d will 
have 
>   to go over it
>   >   again I'm sure, but I clearly see w=
hat Milt is talking 
about.  To 
>   find a stiffer
>   >   deer one would =
have to go to the tundra...
>   > 
>   >   I recall well a tsuba that I fou=
nd many years ago.  It was a 
>   small, copper
>   >   sanmai awase (if I =
correctly remember a phrase I haven't 
uttered 
>   for 15 or more
>   >   =
years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised 
>   (stamped?) wav=
es with a
>   >   creature on it that I always thought was an "over-endowed=
 
>   rabbit", but Bob
>   >   Haynes told me was a fox!!  I wrote to Bob w=
hen I saw a 
similar 
>   tsuba in one of
>   >   his catalogues.  I was am=
azed when he said this was a very 
early 
>   style of tsuba
>   >   ca 130=
0 - 1400.  I had it for years, often looking at it and 
>   saying "Do I li=
ke
>   >   it, or do I not??"  Same thing with this deer kinko.  I have 
> =
  gazed at Pete
>   >   Klein's image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren=
 
Collection 
>   book, but it's
>   >   out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for=
 a long time on this 
sleepless 
>   night, and I
>   >   ask myself the sa=
me question all over again.  So David Z, if 
I 
>   could ask you a
>   >  =
 question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all,  but 
this 
>   is o=
ne of a
>   >   small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would 
=
lead me 
>   to alter my
>   >   policy" I have to ask you "WHY??"  Please =
explain.
>   > 
>   >   If I found this very tsuba I would think it was jun=
k.  I 
don't 
>   have to tell you
>   >   why.  Or do I??  The design spil=
ling into the seppadai I have 
>   only seen on tsuba
>   >   I didn't care=
 for.  The wobbly surface and incredibly bad 
nanako 
>   would kill it
>  =
 >   for me.  And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at 
all.  
>   =
However, I would
>   >   look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine=
 "Hmmm, 
maybe 
>   it's early".
>   >   Back to my question to myself "Do =
I like it, or do I not".  
If I 
>   don't like it,
>   >   I don't collect=
 it, no matter what the aesthetes say.
>   > 
>   >   Now, this puts me int=
o the rustic class, I know, but there is 
a 
>   point to this
>   >   that=
 is not all derisory or derogatory.  It is this.  It is 
easy 
>   to pick
=
>   >   excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the 
iron "wabi-
=
>   sabi" class,
>   >   but the archaic styles, the transition between (if=
 we might 
say) 
>   conceptual
>   >   forerunners and the refined later s=
chools is much, much more 
>   difficult.  Or is
>   >   it??  Recall here =
Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present 
>   discussion.  And I
>   >   =
can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) 
mate 
>   of m=
ine
>   >   dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s".  It is a masterwork of 
la=
te 
>   Edo/early Meiji
>   >   and belongs to a friend of mine.  If he giv=
es permission I'll 
put 
>   up some images
>   >   of it.
>   > 
>   >   S=
o, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting 
the 
>   same=
 closet as
>   >   I???  I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you=
 
like, to 
>   appreciate the
>   >   stiff deer kinko in question and it =
worries me.  It seems 
without 
>   thorough study
>   >   and training man=
y tsuba in this time frame would indeed be 
>   considered junk and
>   >  =
 sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate.  The other kinko 
that 
>   Pet=
e shows in
>   >   two images at the same link does "speak to me".  It is f=
rom 
the 
>   same time frame
>   >   and I find it elegant and refined and=
 would collect it.  I 
think 
>   this discussion
>   >   parallels the Sue=
 Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with 
blades -
>   I don't
>   >   coll=
ect those either...
